Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Remote Sensing of Electron Density Using Auroral Radio Emissions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the role of radio waves in the electromagnetic coupling of the magnetosphere to the ionosphere. In particular it will examine auroral hiss and medium frequency bursts (MFB), which appear in the auroral zones as a prompt response to the onset of a magnetic substorm. In addition to the association with substorm onset, auroral radio emissions are associated with a number of other auroral phenomena, such as poleward-moving arcs and increases in radio wave absorption. The project will use a combination of experimental measurement and theoretical and numerical analysis. An important part of the project will be the measurement of full waveforms and fine structure in MFB events. The waveform measurements will be performed at multiple sites and for multiple events. In some cases it will be possible to use incoherent scatter radar data to determine the plasma density structures within the ionosphere that affect the propagation and dispersion of the waves. Statistical analysis of MFB events, in conjunction with conjugate satellite measurements, will be used to determine the nature of electron precipitation associated with the events. The theoretical and numerical analyses will determine whether or not Langmuir and Z-mode waves can explain the mode conversion processes need to explain the generation of medium frequency bursts.

Magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling and magnetic substorms have been identified as central problems to our understanding of near-earth space plasmas. This project will examine the role that auroral hiss and medium frequency wave bursts play in M-I coupling. Both graduate and undergraduate students will participate in this project in all aspects of the research, including the development of wave measurement instruments, the deployment of the instruments, the analysis of the data obtained from the instruments and the related plasma theory. The majority of the research will take place at Dartmouth College and will offer opportunities for first and second year women to participate in the research through the Dartmouth Women-in-Science Program (WISP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aurora is best known for its beautiful optical displays, but it is also a rich source of radio waves. Just as radio astronomy is an important supplement to optical astronomy, study of radio emissions from the aurora provides valuable insight into upper atmospheric physics, in particular conditions and processes of the charged particle gas in the ionosphere. As part of this project, Dartmouth College used radio observatories at multiple Arctic locations to investigate auroral radio emissions. The project resulted in twelve papers in peer-reviewed journals, eight of which were Dartmouth first-author, and one Dartmouth PhD thesis. Among many outcomes, this project discovered a connection between natural auroral radio emissions and nonlinear waves called "cavitons" detected with the NSF-sponsored scientific radar at Poker Flat, Alaska. The cavitons themselves are mysterious, resulting when the auroral electron beam drives very large amplitude waves; their association with radio emission provides a new tool for detecting them and suggests a possible new radio generation mechanism. Another outcome is the discovery, using the French DEMETER satellite, of space-based observations of a type of auroral radio emission previously observed only from ground-level, providing a new challenge to the theory of those emissions and opening up a new method to study them. Further outcomes included theoretical and modelling work showing the plausibility of a mechanism for generating the "MF-burst" radio emissions developments of theory related to other auroral radio emissions, and observation for the first time of the polarization of low-frequency components of the "MF-burst" radio emissions, which excluded one class of theoretical explanations for them. Data from the Dartmouth radio observatories in Alaska also contributed to studies of radio emissions stimulated by powerful man-made radio transmissions from the HAARP facility. Finally, Dartmouth students and post-docs found ways to exploit the same radio equipment, developed for the auroral studies, to investigate radio and other phenomena in the environment near Hanover, New Hampshire, and in the laboratory. Outcomes of these studies included a first detection of medium-scale atmospheric gravity waves via modulation of the observed carrier frequency of multiple AM radio stations received at multiple sites, caused when the AM signals reflect off of the sinusoidally oscillating ionosphere, and detection of electromagnetic effects including high energy photons from artificial lightning discharges in a laboratory device. In addition to these and other scientific results, this project provided training to multiple undergraduate and graduate students.
